import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
from scipy import stats
from pylab import rcParams
rcParams['figure.figsize'] = 12,6

# to avoid warnings
import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')
warnings.warn("this will not show")

sns.set(style='darkgrid')
%matplotlib inline
source.2cc00331:
def summary(df, pred=None):
    obs = df.shape[0]
    Types = df.dtypes
    Counts = df.apply(lambda x: x.count())
    Min = df.min()
    Max = df.max()
    Uniques = df.apply(lambda x: x.unique().shape[0])
    Nulls = df.apply(lambda x: x.isnull().sum())
    print('Data shape:', df.shape)

    if pred is None:
        cols = ['Types', 'Counts', 'Uniques', 'Nulls', 'Min', 'Max']
        str = pd.concat([Types, Counts, Uniques, Nulls, Min, Max], axis = 1, sort=True)

    str.columns = cols
    print('___________________________\nData Types:')
    print(str.Types.value_counts())
    print('___________________________')
    return str

summary(df)

source.a0a4d1e4:
def box_labels(ax, df,col1,col2):
    medians = df.groupby([col1])[col2].median()
    vertical_offset = df[col2].median() * 0.05 # offset from median for display

    for xtick in ax.get_xticks():
        ax.text(xtick,medians[xtick] + vertical_offset,medians[xtick], 
                horizontalalignment='center',size='x-small',color='w',weight='semibold')

ax = sns.boxplot(x='age', y='time_in_hospital', data=df.sort_values('age'))
box_labels(ax, df.sort_values('age'),'age','time_in_hospital')    
plt.title('Length of Hospital Stay Based on Age')
plt.show()

ax = sns.boxplot(x='readmitted', y='time_in_hospital', data=df.sort_values('readmitted'))
box_labels(ax, df.sort_values('readmitted'),'readmitted','time_in_hospital') 
plt.title('Length of Hospital Stay for Readmitted Patients')
plt.show()

def box_labels(ax, df,col1,col2):
    medians = df.groupby([col1])[col2].median()
    vertical_offset = df[col2].median() * 0.05 # offset from median for display

    for xtick in ax.get_xticks():
        ax.text(xtick,medians[xtick] + vertical_offset,medians[xtick], 
                horizontalalignment='center',size=12,color='w',weight='semibold')

source.ac4ee823:
def labels(ax, df=df):
    for p in ax.patches:
            ax.annotate('%{:.1f}\n{:.0f}'.format(100*p.get_height()/len(df),p.get_height()), 
                        (p.get_x()+0.2, p.get_height()-27),size=16)

# exclude patients without a glucose reading
glucose_none = df[df.max_glu_serum != 'None']

# glucose serum results and readmit impact
ax = sns.countplot(x='max_glu_serum', hue='readmitted', palette='Accent', data=glucose_none)
labels(ax,glucose_none)
plt.title('Readmits By Glucose Serum Levels')
plt.show()

source.0d530ad1: > **Which age group is spending the most time in hospitals during visits?**

source.2adfe13c:
- We got cleaned dataset in the [first notebook](https://www.kaggle.com/kirshoff/01-exploratory-data-analysis-with-diabetes-dataset)
- We use diabetic_data_cleaned.csv here.
source.8bc6428b:
* Most patients have up to nine diagnosed conditions during their visit, after that, only a handful have more than nine in one visit. 
* Readmitted patients tend to have more diagnosed conditions but their average is only slightly higher than those not readmitted.
source.c3971421: > **Do the patients with longer hospital stays have more lab tests?**
source.fb8cfe2f: > Inpatient visits are not common for most patients prior to this visit.
source.15cc3c70: ### FOCUS ON "`number of procedures`" (other than lab)
source.94aa6c2b: > Readmitted patients stay longer in the hospital on average compared to those who are not readmitted.
source.4f6cf43f: Patients with a glucose serum reading of over 300 have a 50-50 chance of being readmitted. High blood sugar levels are often dangerous for older patients due to the medical complications involved, so it's understandable that more patients return to the hospital for additional care.
source.e23b046f: > **What is the comparison of time in hospital for readmitted patients?**
source.29f687f1:
* We are looking for correlations between the independent variables and the target variable, the likelihood of being readmitted to the hospital, using graphs and plots. 
* This is also a good time to get a better understanding of patient demographics, their experiences at the hospital, medications being used / not used, and any diagnosed conditions.
source.7572d89c: > **How many emergency visits did patients have prior to this visit?**
source.05feac72: >In every age group, more patients are not readmitted. The 70-80 age group account has the highest number of readmitted and not readmitted patients.
source.4200dc83: > The distribution is almost equal for readmitted and not readmitted patients, with readmits being slightly higher on average.
source.2f8065c7:
* The average number of lab procedures is about equal for readmitted and not readmitted patients. 
* Not readmitted patients have a slightly lower number of lab procedures done during their visit.
source.7a8fc5e5: > **How many medications are patients receiving during their visit?**
source.e4b9c208:
* There is a positive correlation between time spent in the hospital and number of lab tests completed. 
* This makes sense since patients with longer stays had more tests completed to properly diagnose their conditions.
source.a9e33327: > **Do the number of tests performed indicate whether a patient will be readmitted?**
source.207abc2b: > **How many medications are patients receiving during their visit?**
source.93c301ef: > **How many diagnoses do readmitted patients have?**
source.621400b0: > Based on the graph, the longer a patient spends in the hospital, the likelier their chances are of being readmitted. Patients who spend more than a week in the hospital usually have a serious illness or complication that may reoccur depending on their ability to recover, which is why they may need to revisit the hospital.
source.aad5af3a: > Patients who spend more time in the hospital receive more medications, but there are a few that receive over 60 different kinds of medications.
source.509cb9be:
* Similar to the glucose reading, the majority of patients also do not have a HbA1c test reading. 
* In order to understand the impact of A1c tests on readmit rates, patients without a reading will be excluded in the graph below.

source.0639c4bd: Glikoz serum okuması 300'ün üzerinde olan hastaların readmit orani 50-50'dir. Yüksek kan şekeri seviyeleri, tıbbi komplikasyonlar nedeniyle genellikle yaşlı hastalar için tehlikelidir, bu nedenle daha fazla hastanın ek bakım için hastaneye dönmesi anlaşılabilir bir durumdur.
